ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SALE OF CHILLED MEAT IN WET MARKETS

(Provision of chillers)


    1. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for the Environment whether his Ministry will facilitate the sale of chilled meat by retrofitting wet markets with chillers for use by meat sellers.

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, as announced on 23rd April 1999, chilled fresh meat supplied to wet markets will have to be sold in display chillers. This will ensure that the meat sold in the wet markets is safe and hygienic.

    Stallholders selling pork in wet markets will have to install display chillers by 1st November 1999. Those selling poultry have one year to put in their display chillers and those selling mutton and beef 18 months to do likewise.

    The stallholders will have to buy the display chillers themselves. The cost of the chiller, at between $3,000 and $6,000, is not exorbitant. The investment in a chiller is a business decision that stallholders need to make if they wish to remain in the business of selling meat.

    So far, three finance companies have informed my Ministry that they are prepared to offer loans of between 80% and 95% of the cost of the chillers, with repayment over one to four years and interest rates of between 3.5% and 4% per annum.

    Four suppliers of chillers have also agreed to allow interest-free instalment payments.

    The Government on its part will spend some $6.5 million to upgrade electricity supply in the wet markets to enable the chillers to operate.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, may I ask the Minister if ENV would assist those meat sellers in our wet markets who

Column: 1290

have financial difficulties to retrofit and install the chillers in their stalls?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, as I mentioned just now, those stallholders who are facing difficulties paying for the chillers can obtain loans to buy the chillers. They can get the loan from the finance companies and, as I mentioned, some of the companies are prepared to offer 4-year loans at fairly attractive interest rates of 3.5% to 4%.

    Dr Lily Neo: In such circumstances, would the Minister consider installing the chillers for them and allowing them to pay by instalments?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, it is best for the stallholders to decide which particular chiller best meets their business volume. If they are prepared to pay by instalments, they might as well get the loans directly from the finance companies. Assuming they get a bigger chiller which costs $6,000 and they pay over four years or 50 repayments, I think the monthly instalment is very affordable.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Could the Minister give some ballpark figures of the cost of the chiller or the monthly instalments vis-a-vis the monthly rental or the average income of these stallholders?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, it depends very much on the size of the chiller and the length of the repayment period that they opt for. If you take a smaller chiller which costs about $3,000, and divide it by three years, it is $1,000 a year or about $100 a month. Some of the stallholders sell up to about 10 pigs a day which would fetch them a turnover of about $3,500. In terms of the cost per month versus the turnover, I think the cost comprises a very small percentage of the turnover.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Sir, that is a percentage of the turnover. What about the percentage of the income?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, we do not know exactly how much the hawkers

Column: 1291

make. But my assumption is that the profit level must be quite attractive because there are about 1,000 stallholders selling pork in Singapore and the fact that already 107 stallholders have placed their orders for the chillers shows that it is a business decision which they are prepared to take and make and the purchase of the chillers still makes the business of selling pork a very viable and attractive one.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Sir, may I ask the Minister a serious question whether he would start a campaign for people to eat more vegetables and fish?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, in my other hat, as the Minister for Health, in fact, that is what we have been doing, ie, encouraging Singaporeans to live a healthy lifestyle which includes having a well-balanced diet. This means not just having meat but also having a healthy spread of other items like vegetables.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, may I ask the Minister why the stallholders must install chillers now and not before, and could chillers solve the problem of Japanese Encephalitis (JE)?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, in fact, the plan to move to the cold chain has been in discussion for quite some time and the recent episode of JE and the Nipah virus highlighted the need for us to speed up this plan. Why do we need to go to the chilled meat and the cold chain system? Under the old system, the animals were slaughtered and they were straightaway brought to the markets, which means there was very little time for the proper analysis to be carried out as to whether that pig was in any way infected. By having the chilled meat system, it allows the abattoirs to hold on to the meat after slaughter and it ensures that the blood and the internal organs can be properly analysed. By having the chilled meat system we will in fact be in a better position to assure Singaporeans that the meat that they buy from the markets is well inspected and found to be free of diseases.

Column: 1292



    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: What this really means is that in a way consumers have no choice in the matter. Is it not possible to leave this as a matter of choice? In other words, for those who want chillers to be installed, by all means install chillers and the basis of that is a possible improvement in health; for those who want to continue to eat fresh meat, allow them to do so.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, once the meat is chilled it is proper and best to sell it as chilled. The reason is that when the meat is chilled and left in the open, especially in our very humid environment, a lot of moisture forms on the meat and that actually speeds up deterioration of the meat. So we must ensure that the meat remains chilled up to the point of sale.

DETECTION OF NIPAH VIRUS IN SHEEP AND DOGS
(Steps to monitor development)



    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Gerard Ee -

    2. To ask the Minister for National Development in view of the press and radio reports that the Nipah virus has been detected in sheep and dogs, what steps are being taken by his Ministry to monitor this new development.

    Mr Chuang Shaw Peng (Nominated Member): Question No. 2, Sir.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Nipah virus, or formerly known as the Hendra-like virus, is a newly discovered virus. Currently, little is known about the new Nipah virus. Experts from the US Center of Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, and the Australian Animal Health Laboratories are still investigating the cases in Malaysia and carrying out more studies on the nature and epidemiology of the Nipah virus.

    Although there have been recent reports of Nipah virus infection in dogs and goats in Malaysia, there is no risk of the spread of the Nipah virus to Singapore via animal hosts. This is because PPD has imposed a ban on the import of all

Column: 1293

mammals, including goats and dogs, from Malaysia since 19th March 1999. The control measures taken by PPD are still in place today. PPD will not lift this ban until it is confident that the import of animals will not pose a danger to public health. PPD and the Customs Department have also stepped up surveillance to prevent smuggling of meat and animals into Singapore.

    In addition, PPD is also monitoring closely the situation and developments in Malaysia, especially the recent occurrence of the Nipah virus in Johor. It maintains close contact with the American and Australian experts and the Malaysian veterinary authorities so that it is kept updated of the latest findings and developments promptly. PPD will respond swiftly if the studies or developments suggest that other additional precautions are necessary in future.

    The current ban on pig imports from Malaysia remains and we will resume imports from Johor only when the area can be declared to be a disease-free zone according to international standards.

Column: 1293

ELECTRONIC ROAD PRICING DEFAULTERS


    3. Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung asked the Minister for Communications if he will update the House on what non-criminal measures will be taken to deal with electronic road pricing defaulters.

    4. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider a violation of the use of Cashcards and In-Vehicle Units as a minor or unintentional offence, requiring only the collection of a higher rate of fees payable from the car owner through a monthly or even six-monthly invoice.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 3 and 4 together?

    Mr Speaker: Yes, you may.

Column: 1294



    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Thank you. Sir, in March this year, during the Budget debate, Prof. Chin and Mr Chay Wai Chuen raised similar queries about the penalties for ERP violations. Most ERP violations arise from motorists either inserting their Cashcards improperly, or forgetting to insert their Cashcards, or having insufficient balances in their Cashcards. As it is not possible for motorists to evade detection under the ERP system, my Ministry agrees that such violations are not due to wilful disregard for our rules but to forgetfulness or carelessness.

    I then informed the House that the Land Transport Authority (LTA) was working out a scheme to allow motorists who commit these ERP violations to pay the ERP charges and an administrative surcharge. I am pleased to announce that the LTA has finalised the details of this scheme.

    Under the revised system, motorists who forget to insert their Cashcards into the IUs or have insufficient balance in their Cashcards when passing through ERP gantries, will be required to pay the applicable ERP fee plus an administrative surcharge within two weeks of the violation. The administrative surcharge is currently set at $10. The LTA will send a letter to the motorist informing him of the violation, and requesting him to pay up the charges within two weeks. If he does not do so within the 2-week period, he will then have to pay a composition fine of $70.

    LTA will announce implementation details of this scheme soon.

    With regard to Dr Neo's suggestion on a monthly or 6-monthly invoice, my Ministry had considered such a central billing system for the collection of ERP charges and violations when the ERP system was first designed but opted for the present smart-card system for several reasons. This is because the smart-card system does away with the need for an expensive central accounting billing operation. It also makes motorists more conscious of the cost of motoring as the deduction is immediate each time the vehicle passes under a gantry. Finally, the

Column: 1295

current system using Cashcards also safeguards individual privacy as details of movements of motorists would not be monitored. Nevertheless, we will continue to monitor the situation and refine the system as and when necessary.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the current defaulters are still liable for the composition fine or they will be treated under the new scheme?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, in order for the new scheme to come into operation, changes will have to be made to the administrative system and that will take some time. LTA will require some more time before it can implement the system. So current defaulters under the scheme would continue to be treated according to the present administrative regime.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): May I ask the Minister about the administrative charge of $10? Could he enlighten the House as to what is it for that this administrative charge is levied? Is it for sending a notice to the owner of the car?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as the name suggests, the administrative charge is to cover all the costs related to the administration of this new scheme which include the tracking of the offences, making sure that the motorists who do not pay the ERP charge do so within the two weeks and if they do not, making sure that they are issued the composition fine of $70. All this involves administration, manpower, computer time and it also involves the setting up of a total framework to make sure that such a violation scheme is not abused. After all, the purpose of this scheme is to make sure that motorists do use the system as it is intended, which is to have an IU installed, to have a valid CashCard inserted and to make sure that each time a motorist uses an ERP-controlled road, he pays the fee. More than 99% of people do that.

    To cater to the small group of people who forget to do so, we have amended the system, according to feedback from Members of this House. We agree that

Column: 1296

under the ERP system, nobody can escape. Unlike the old system where people had to put up a disc, and some who did not put up a disc were not people who forgot to do so, but were people who were out to cheat the system. And that was when a composition fine was imposed. Under the ERP system, such a situation does not occur, because every motorist who passes through the gantry will be detected. So, on that basis, we have decided to change the system, and I hope motorists will continue to use the system as it is intended. But if they do not for whatever reason - forgetfulness, carelessness or whatever - they are not overly penalised, as it were.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: I am thankful to the Minister for the lengthy reply he has given, but I regret it does not really answer my question. Would he set out specifically what is this administration for which $10 appears to be the just punishment?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: I do not know where the hon. Member got the idea of a punishment from. I have just gone through a lengthy reply to the Member of the House to explain to him that we do not regard this as an offence. We regard this as non-payment of a fee. We wish to collect that fee and therefore we have to go through this exercise. The process of going through that exercise incurs expenses and manpower, and the charge for this expense and manpower is, at the moment, $10. It could go up, if the cost of administration goes up. But as far as we are concerned, at this stage, we are recovering the cost of administration, plus the ERP fee.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, would the Minister explain why he finds it fit to levy a $70 compound fine when the current fine, I believe, is $30?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, if the letter asking for payment is sent out and if within two weeks, no reply is given, that is tantamount to an offence. For such an offence, a levy of $70 is deemed to be the charge. In other words, a motorist is given two weeks to pay up, failing which he is

Column: 1297

deemed to have committed an offence. In the same way that he does not pay a parking charge or he does not pay any other Government charge, he is deemed to have committed an offence. And a notice of offence is then sent out.

Column: 1297

ELECTRONIC ROAD PRICING SYSTEM AND AREA
LICENSING SCHEME



    5. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for Communications if he will provide a comparison of the Electronic Road Pricing system with the Area Licensing Scheme and the changes which have occurred with regard to (i) road traffic patterns and (ii) revenue collected.

    6. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Communications (a) whether his Ministry has evaluated the business cost implications of extending the electronic road pricing in September 1999; and (b) whether it has considered levying a lower charge on commercial vehicles to bring down their business costs.

    7. Mr Shriniwas Rai asked the Minister for Communications when the Land Transport Authority will release the fee to be charged at the new 9 Electronic Road Pricing gantries.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Questions 5, 6 and 7 together as they are related?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the ERP is a critical policy instrument to manage congestion on our roads. Together with the Vehicle Quota System, they keep our roads flowing freely, so that goods and people do not get stuck in traffic jams. In other words, and this is in response to Mr Tay's question, the ERP has had a positive impact on business, not only in direct cash terms but also in terms of faster travel times that lead to overall lowering of transport costs. This ultimately helps us to maintain our competitiveness as an efficient international manufacturing, logistics and business centre.

Column: 1298



    As our vehicle population expands, in order to cater to growing demands from business and to meet the aspirations of our people, the challenge to keep congestion at bay will become increasingly more difficult. Our choices are limited. We can build more roads, but we will have to sacrifice land for housing, schools, industries and recreation. This is not an option for most Singaporeans. We can restrain car growth. Again, this is not an option if we are to give young Singaporeans and those who can afford their chance to own a car. Finally, we can manage the traffic on our roads, by encouraging better use of our limited road space through ERP. This is the preferred option. With ERP, motorists are more careful about using their vehicles. They have several choices. Do they have to drive? Can they take a bus or train? Can they share a car with friends or colleagues? Or can they switch their travel to a less congested time? If they really need to drive at peak hours, they are free to do so, and in return for a small fee, they enjoy a smoother and faster ride.

    Our experience with ERP and ALS has been positive. In 1975, when road pricing was first introduced, total vehicle population was 280,000. Today, it is 680,000, an increase of almost 150%. Over the same period, our road network has increased by 44%. Trips made by public transport has gone up by about 90%. The bottom line is that while cars have increased, our roads are still free-flowing because more people are using public transport.

    However, pockets of congestion are appearing in areas outside the CBD and along the expressways. Moreover, they are spreading from the morning to the evening peak hours as well. This is not surprising as our vehicle population is continuing to expand faster than our road capacity. That is why we need to expand the ERP.

    The LTA will shortly announce the exact locations of the first seven gantries to be implemented on 1st September 1999. Other gantries will be considered when the traffic conditions demand them.

    Mr Rai asked about the rates that will be charged at these gantries. They will only

Column: 1299

be fixed closer to the date of implementation, ie, in September 1999, based on the prevailing traffic conditions then.

    Mr Tay asked about lowering charges for commercial vehicles. When ERP was introduced last year, the Government, as promised, lowered the cost of vehicle ownership. Up-front and annual ownership taxes such as Customs Duties, Registration Fees, Additional Registration Fees and road tax were significantly reduced. The majority of vehicle owners, including owners of commercial vehicles, enjoyed substantial savings in annual road tax, ranging from about $280 per year for cars to as much as $2,000 per year for commercial vehicles. In addition, all vehicle owners were given a road tax rebate of $200 per PCU.

    We have also helped businesses to adjust to ERP by phasing in the charges for commercial vehicles over four years. Currently, commercial vehicles pay only a quarter of their full ERP rates, except for the CTE, where they pay half the rate. Whether it is quarter or half, this is still much lower than what they were paying under the manual road pricing scheme. In fact, owners of commercial vehicles will save about $63 million in the first year of ERP implementation.

    Dr Lee asked for a comparison between the ERP and the manual Area Licensing Scheme (ALS). With ERP, traffic is now better spread out with charges corresponding more closely to traffic conditions. Travel speeds in the Restricted Zone (RZ) range from 20 to 30 km per hour and on the expressways between 45 and 65 km per hour. At these speeds, the roads and expressways are carrying close to their designed capacity while remaining congestion free.

    ERP rates are also lower than the corresponding ALS fees. For example, the ALS fee for cars was $3.00 during peak periods and $2.00 during off-peak periods. Now, with ERP, the Restricted Zone rates range from $1.00 to $2.50. And on Saturdays, it is now free entry.

    Government revenue from ERP today is about 60% of the revenue under

Column: 1300

the manual ALS/RPS schemes. This is expected to decrease further following the last rate adjustment in April 1999, which saw the lifting of ERP on Saturdays and reductions in charges for some time periods in the RZ and on one of the Expressways. This demonstrates clearly that ERP is a traffic management tool, not a revenue-generating instrument. The objective of ERP, I repeat again, is to keep our roads congestion free and smooth flowing while allowing our vehicle population to increase. In so doing, it helps to maintain Singapore as an attractive and efficient place to live in and do business in.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Sir, the Minister mentioned that the ERP system has led to an overall lowering of transport costs and that Government revenue has decreased to 60% of that under the ALS scheme. However, we do not know from the consumers' point of view, in other words, the motorists' point of view, whether it has actually taken them a longer time to reach their destinations because of travelling on alternative routes, or that they actually had to rearrange their time schedules in order to have a reduction in terms of price. Therefore, we do not necessarily know that from the motorists' point of view there is an overall reduction in terms of all sorts of costs, including time. Would the Minister therefore consider doing a survey to find out from motorists how they have actually adjusted their traffic patterns and whether they have saved in terms not only of cost but also in terms of time travelled?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the purpose of the ERP is not just to spread the traffic. If we take it from the point of view of what Dr Lee mentioned where people are just avoiding the traffic jams alone, I think that in itself is not going to solve the problem. The purpose of this exercise is to offer more than just that option. There are other options involved which include - and this is most important - either a forgoing of trips because the trips are not necessary or a shift from private to public transport.

    We have not done a comprehensive survey because we have just started to

    Kindness and graciousness are two very rare commodities in any modern urban society. They are rare because the practice of it has been forgotten. City life is stressful, lonely, quick-paced and cold. City life is to be endured because of the material benefits it brings to the family. But city life in the end is dehumanising. The city inhabitant is a faceless, anonymous digit in the crowd. He lives only for himself and ensures that whatever he does is to guarantee the survival of his family and his kin and himself. In such an environment, kindness and graciousness do not grow. In such an environment, the buffet tables get swiped clean two minutes after they are laid out but mountains of wasted food are left to be cleared later. Queues are for jumping, free textbooks are for grabbing and waiters and maids are for venting out the frustrations. It is a heartless and compassionless society and nothing to be proud of.

    In the nick of time comes this report, this vision - before our community becomes too much like the ugly, urban society I have just described. A knowledge-based economy is one which values everyone and gives everyone a role and a place, a name and a face, kindness and grace. In a knowledge-based economy, there is no job that is despised. Even the humble cleaning worker, the waiter, the plumber and the taxi driver are knowledge workers, not just the IT men. State Of Discipline In Schools

    The overall state of discipline in our schools is good. Serious cases of breach of discipline are infrequent.



    MOE has implemented the Behaviour Tracking and Analysis (BETA) system in schools since 1995. The system collects data on the state of discipline in individual schools. For primary schools, misdemeanours such as not doing assignments and disruptive behaviour, and attendance-related offences, constitute 84% of all the recorded offences. In the secondary schools, 74% of the offences were attendance-related, namely, late-coming and truancy.

    The BETA records show no significant statistical change in the offence rates from 1995 to 1997. "Offence rates" refers to the number of offences per 1000 pupils. The data for 1998 show the number of serious offences such as gangsterism and possession of weapons remaining close to that of 1997, and the number of cases of substance abuse falling from 272 in 1997 to 40 in 1998. However, the incidence of smoking has risen from 14 per 1000 pupils over the three years 1995 -1997 to 19 per 1000 pupils in 1998.

    The overall offence rate for boys has remained stable over the years, but a worrying trend is the increasing offence rate for girls in the secondary schools. Though lower than the male offence rates, the female offence rates have increased by 6% to 9% per year over the last 4 years, going up from 300 in 1995 to 456 in 1998.

    A committee chaired by the Senior Minister of State for Education, Dr Aline Wong, was set up in May last year to look into the discipline situation among girls in schools. The committee is finalising its recommendations.

    

Measures To Address Discipline in Schools

    The Ministry's philosophy is that to care is to discipline. Schools by and large take a whole-person approach to discipline. They have many programmes and support structures to help promote discipline. Besides the creation of the posts of Discipline Master, Head/Pupil Welfare and, most recently, Operations Manager, there is also the Voluntary Special Constabulary Scheme where teachers assume the mantle of law enforcement officers to help reinforce an orderly school environment.

    Teachers have been equipped with basic counselling skills and many spend much time counselling errant students. Such efforts are complemented by programmes like life skills and peer mediation.

    However, discipline of students is not just the responsibility of schools. Parents must remain primarily responsible for their children, particularly outside of school hours. While the Ministry does not have data on ill-discipline outside school, schools do work closely with the Neighbourhood Police Posts through the NPP-School Link-Up Scheme. Many schools also mount before-and-after-school programmes to keep their students gainfully engaged in school activities.

    14. Mrs Lim Hwee Hua asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the incidence of crime by illegal immigrants or overstayers has risen over the last twelve months and what steps are being taken to keep such incidence in check.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng:

    The incidence of crime by illegal immigrants and overstayers has remained low. In 1998, the number of crimes committed by immigration offenders was about 250. This is about 0.5% of the total number of seizable offences reported in 19981. Of the 1929 foreigners arrested for crimes in 1998, 210 (10.9%) were illegal immigrants and 46 (2.4%) were overstayers. These immigration offenders were mostly involved in minor offences, such as shoplifting.

    It is not practical to devise specific measures targeted only at the immigration offenders involved in crime. Hence, my Ministry's approach is to deter and take tough enforcement action against all immigration offenders in Singapore. In this regard, we have enhanced the penalties in the Immigration Act. Immigration officers have stepped up their vigilance at our checkpoints, the Coast Guard has intensified its patrols and surveillance of suspicious activities at sea, and the Police has conducted islandwide raids at suspected places of refuge. This has led to a record high of 23,000 in the total number of illegal immigrants and overstayers arrested in 1998.

    The Home Team will maintain its enforcement efforts to ensure that the immigration offender situation and the associated crime problems remain firmly under control.

FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE


    2. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for National Development whether there is any danger of the foot and mouth disease spreading to Singapore from Malaysia in view of the recent outbreak of the virus in Negri Sembilan.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang:

    The foot and mouth disease (FMD) is a serious viral disease affecting cloven hoof animals such as cattle, pigs, sheep and goats. However, FMD does not affect humans and is, therefore, not a health risk to the general public. I would like to clarify that the Foot and Mouth Disease is totally unrelated to the human disease called Hand-Foot-and-Mouth disease.

    We have managed to keep Singapore free from FMD over the years even though it is endemic in the region. To maintain Singapore's FMD free status, the Primary Production Department (PPD) allows cloven hoof animals to be imported from FMD free sources only. As for Malaysia, PPD only allows imports from accredited farms in the FMD free areas. Upon arrival in Singapore, the animal consignments are inspected for signs of disease. In addition, animals, such as dairy cattle, brought in from FMD free countries for breeding and production are required to go through at least 30 days of on-farm quarantine in a specified isolated area.

    Singapore is free from FMD. I see no reason why we cannot maintain this position.

    The current ban on the import of pigs, cattle, horses, dogs, cats and other mammals from Malaysia imposed by PPD since 19th March 1999 for the pig problem will also be effective against the spread of foot and mouth disease to the animals here.
